highSignals: Explicit methodology keywords: qualitative, ethnography, grounded theory, discourse analysis, narrative inquiry, phenomenology, interviews, focus groups, participatory research, CBPR, oral history, thematic analysis, case study research
Fields with strong qualitative foundations: sociology, anthropology, social work, communication studies, education research, nursing research, medical humanities

Research topics requiring human-centered methods: stigma, lived experience, identity, families, communities, health equity/disparities, violence prevention, child welfare, sexual/reproductive health, LGBTQ+ health, trauma, migration, racism
Participatory and community language: partnering with communities, community-based, centering voices, underserved/marginalized populations, co-production, collaborative research
Academic research leadership roles with population focus: PI, lab director, center director, research scientist studying human populations
Sensitive population research requiring IRB and participant management: HIV/AIDS, mental health, suicide/self-harm, child abuse, sexual health, immigration, incarceration
lowSignals: Clinical-only roles: MD, fellow, resident without PI/researcher designation
Quantitative-primary fields: epidemiologist (unless 'social'), biostatistics, data science, computational methods, demographer (unless mixed with sociology)
Support roles without research leadership: research coordinator, research assistant, clinical research specialist
Theoretical-only scholars: pure bioethicists, postcolonial literary theorists, STS theorists without empirical fieldwork
Industry UX researchers without academic connection
Policy analysts without fieldwork or participant research
falsePositivePatterns: Bioethicists discussing ethics without conducting participant research
Postcolonial/literary scholars doing textual analysis only (no interviews/fieldwork)
STS researchers focused on theory/policy rather than ethnographic work
Public health researchers with pure quantitative/surveillance focus
Clinical psychologists doing intervention trials (not qualitative exploration)
UX researchers in industry without IRB-level participant management needs
domainContext: Target users conduct human-subjects research requiring: participant recruitment and tracking, interview/focus group scheduling, transcription services (including multilingual), IRB compliance documentation, secure storage for sensitive qualitative data, and team collaboration on coding/analysis. They study populations and phenomena through direct human interaction - interviews, observations, focus groups - not purely through surveys, databases, or textual analysis.

definitiveMatch: Explicit 'qualitative', 'ethnography', 'grounded theory', 'narrative inquiry', 'discourse analysis' in bio = 0.90+
PI/lab director studying stigma, equity, trauma, lived experience = 0.85+
likelyMatch: STS researcher with explicit fieldwork/participant mention = 0.70+
capScores: MD/clinical fellow without 'researcher' or 'PI' = cap at 0.40
Bioethicist without empirical research signals = cap at 0.50
Postcolonial/literary scholar without fieldwork = cap at 0.50
Demographer without sociology/qualitative mention = cap at 0.50

actualCustomerPatterns: Sociologists studying families, migration, health - topic-based not method-stated
Social work professors partnering with communities
Faculty studying HIV stigma, sexual/reproductive health
PIs in trauma, psychosocial factors research
Health equity center directors with sociology background
Sexuality researchers at institutes like Kinsey
commonFalsePositives: Bioethicists (discuss ethics but don't recruit participants)
STS theorists (study science/tech but don't do ethnography)
Postcolonial literary scholars (textual analysis not interviews)
Clinical psychologists (intervention trials not exploratory qual)
Public health epidemiologists (surveillance not participant research)
